title: Rosetta Luce Gilchrist
text:
Rosetta Luce Gilchrist (, Luce; April 11, 1850February 17, 1921) was an American physician, author, novelist, poet, and correspondent. She served as president of the <a href="Ashtabula%20County%2C%20Ohio">Ashtabula</a> Equal Rights Club. Gilchrist died in 1921.
Biography.
Rosetta Luce was born in <a href="Kingsville%2C%20Ohio">Kingsville</a>, <a href="Ashtabula%20County%2C%20Ohio">Ashtabula County</a>, <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a>, April 11, 1850. In youth, she was a student in the Kingsville, or Rexville, Academy. She graduated from <a href="Oberlin%20College">Oberlin College</a> in 1870. In 1890, she graduated from the <a href="List%20of%20defunct%20medical%20schools%20in%20the%20United%20States">Cleveland Homeopathic Medical College</a>.
Gilchrist was a successful teacher in the Cleveland public schools. After graduating from medical school, she gained a lucrative practice in the medical profession. Though she gave little attention to literature, her chief talent lay in that direction. Her early work, "Apples of Sodom", was a piece of <a href="Anti-Mormonism">anti-Mormon</a> fiction. Other publications included "Margaret's Sacrifice", "Thistledew Papers", and numerous poems. Gilchrist served as a correspondent for various newspapers. She was a member of the <a href="National%20Woman%27s%20Press%20Association">National Woman's Press Association</a> and the <a href="Cleveland">Cleveland</a> Woman's Press Association and president of the Ashtabula Equal Rights Club.
Gilchrist was a talented artist, having done some excellent work in oils, wholly without instruction. She had a family of three children, including a daughter, Jessamine.
